awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Privacy aware information systems using contextual integrity principle
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide a privacy design framework that leverages contextual integrity (CI) principles combined with formal logic methods to enable organizations and end users to build new forms of privacy aware information systems. The privacy design framework addresses a fundamental privacy gap in existing information systems in large organizations between system level privacy guarantees and privacy expectations of end users. It is envisioned that the privacy design framework will be a service that enables ordinary users to express complex privacy rules in an organization based on CI principles.  It will also leverage formal logic methods to convert contextual integrity rules to logic programs that verify the privacy properties of information flows within the organization. This privacy framework aims to ease the development of new privacy aware information systems that support the full spectrum of stakeholders in organizations including end users, administrators, system designers and regulators. It can enable greater transparency for regulators, data protection authorities, administrators and end users.

This I-Corps project will evaluate privacy as a service design framework using the principles of contextual integrity theory that offers system designers the tools to clearly articulate, design and implement privacy policies in large scale information systems, where the privacy policies clearly match the privacy expectations of end users. The privacy framework makes three fundamental research contributions:  (i) The framework uses the theory of contextual integrity to formalize informational norms as logical rules that constitute a privacy logic of the system, thereby providing the ability to reason about privacy in complex information systems; (ii) The framework is modular and domain agnostic where it decouples specification of privacy logic from the enforcement of privacy checks on information flows within the system while requiring minimal modifications to the underlying system; (iii) The system leverages formal logic methods to ensure the correctness of privacy policy specifications and ensures that information exchange within the system strictly follows the established privacy norms of a given context.

por.por_cntn:
Our project focuses on a privacy-design framework that leverages contextual integrity (CI) principles combined with formal logic methods to enable organizations and end-users to build new forms of privacy-aware information systems. The main goal of the I-corps award was to validate our business value proposition through intensive and comprehensive customer discovery process. We had three basic goals in our customer discovery experience:

* Validate our business value proposition
* Put together a viable business plan 
* Test our business assumptions and hypothesis regarding the product and how it can be used in practice

We were focused on different customer verticals to understand market needs on privacy-centric problems that need to be addressed including finance, healthcare, enteprise, startups and non-tech companies.

During the ICORPS program,  we interviewed privacy experts, CTOs, CEOs, CIOs, CPOs, managers, product managers, legal experts, privacy lawyers and software engineers in over 100 companies. We wanted to uncover some of the hard problems that they are facing in protecting users information including:

* Identifying the major privacy issues in the enterprise space
* Refining the value proposition
* Identifying the relevant market/customer segment for our product.

Our initial goal started with highly regulated market segments like health and finance and we realized several layers of existing regulations and solutions that have been deeply ingrained in these markets. In general, our solution direction did not exactly match with this sector.

This next led us to technology based business, small startups and non-technology but data-driven companies like Macys and Jon Deers. Here, we found some traction in the match between their problem and our research directions. There was a need to develop a privacy dashboard that could aid the privacy and compliance divisions of the company to track information flows within and outside an organization. Many administrative errors can trigger privacy compliance problems and having a dashboard that could track the broad spectrum of privacy relevant flows in a large and small organization seem like a definite market need.

Through this experience, we were able to achieve the following significant results:

* The process provided the team with a unique insight into how sensitive information is handled in various enterprise settings.

* We have a better understanding how our research can be utilized by the industry to translate into a viable product prototype

* We have a clearer understanding of our value proposition and the relevant stakeholders in the space.

* We have a better understanding of the target market for our research and products.

In summay, from our Icorps experience, we realized that there is potential for a privacy compliance product for mid-size startups and data-driven non-technology companies. For both sectors having a privacy dashboard that can keep track of information flows within the enterprise and show-case potential compliance issues to the CIOs, CEOs (of small startups), chief privacy/compliance officers (non-technology organizations) in these organizations. 

Our current research prototype is very far from the type of privacy product we determined as relevant for the market. Hence, the final outcome of our ICorps experience was a no-go decision. This could be a temporary decision for the upcoming year where we are working towards revising our research ideas towards making it more market relevant. The ICorps experience has also directly influenced some of the new research we need to pursue to address the identified challenges including understanding GDPR laws.

We are currently seeking research funding to pursue some of these ideas over the upcoming year or two before we believe our research becomes more ready for the privacy market. We believe we are definitely in the right direction but certainly not ready for launching a startup in this space yet.
